verses.text: Here are the stages of the Israelites’ journey when they came out of the land of Egypt by their divisions, under the leadership of Moses and Aaron:
verses.comment: This verse introduces a recounting of the Exodus journey. The mention of Moses and Aaron emphasizes leadership and obedience to divine instructions, which foreshadows apostolic succession and structured community life.

verses.text: Moses recorded their starting points according to the stages by the command of the LORD. These are their stages according to their starting points:
verses.comment: Moses’ recording of events reflects a focus on preserving tradition and sacred history. Written accounts help preserve the faith and ensure continuity.

verses.text: They set out from Rameses in the first month, on the fifteenth day of the first month. On the day after the Passover, the Israelites went out boldly in sight of all the Egyptians.
verses.comment: Leaving Egypt immediately after Passover signifies salvation through sacrifice, foreshadowing Christ as the true Passover Lamb (cf. 1 Cor. 5:7). The boldness of their departure reminds believers of the courage needed in following God's call.

verses.text: While the Egyptians were burying all their firstborn, whom the LORD had struck down among them; upon their gods also the LORD executed judgments.
verses.comment: God's judgment on Egypt extends to their gods, showing His supreme authority over false deities. This event foreshadows the ultimate defeat of evil through Christ.

verses.text: The Israelites set out from Rameses and camped at Succoth.
verses.comment: Each stage marks a specific act of deliverance and God's guidance, highlighting the journey of faith.

verses.text: They departed from Succoth and camped at Etham, which is on the edge of the wilderness.
verses.comment: Etham marks the boundary before entering the wilderness, symbolizing transition and trust in divine providence.

verses.text: They set out from Etham and turned back toward Pi Hahiroth, which faces Baal Zephon; and they camped before Migdol.
verses.comment: This detour led up to the crossing of the Red Sea, a redemptive act reflecting baptism’s role as passage from slavery to freedom in Christian life (cf. 1 Cor. 10:2).

verses.text: They departed from before Pi Hahiroth and crossed through the middle of the sea into the wilderness, and went three days’ journey in the wilderness of Etham, and camped at Marah.
verses.comment: The three-day journey and the bitter waters at Marah allude to spiritual purification and preparation, which has parallel to the three days between Christ’s death and resurrection.

verses.text: They set out from Marah and came to Elim; and at Elim there were twelve springs of water and seventy palm trees, and they camped there.
verses.comment: Twelve springs symbolize the twelve tribes of Israel and later the twelve apostles (cf. Matthew 10:2), while seventy palms suggest universal mission.

verses.text: They left Elim and camped by the Red Sea.
verses.comment: The repeated return to water sources highlights dependence on God's provision, prefiguring the sacramental life.

verses.text: They set out from the Red Sea and camped in the wilderness of Sin.
verses.comment: The wilderness of Sin is the setting for the gift of manna, symbolizing God’s daily provision and prefiguring the Eucharist (cf. John 6:32-35).

verses.text: They departed from the wilderness of Sin and camped at Dophkah.
verses.comment: The continual movement reflects spiritual progression and dependence on divine guidance.

verses.text: They set out from Dophkah and camped at Alush.
verses.comment: Each named place represents both historical fact and spiritual meaning for the journey of faith.

verses.text: They departed from Alush and camped at Rephidim, where there was no water for the people to drink.
verses.comment: Rephidim reveals the need to trust God, who provides water from the rock, a spiritual type of Christ (cf. 1 Cor. 10:4).

verses.text: They set out from Rephidim and camped in the wilderness of Sinai.
verses.comment: Mount Sinai marks the giving of the Law, establishing a covenant community, reminiscent of the structure and authority given in Christ’s Church.

verses.text: They left the wilderness of Sinai and camped at Kibroth Hattaavah.
verses.comment: Kibroth Hattaavah was the place of judgment for craving meat, highlighting the consequences of disobedience.

verses.text: They departed from Kibroth Hattaavah and camped at Hazeroth.
verses.comment: Hazeroth was the place of Miriam's leprosy—a lesson in humility, repentance, and restoration.

verses.text: They set out from Hazeroth and camped at Rithmah.
verses.comment: Rithmah’s location is linked with the wilderness of Paran, a place of testing and preparation for God’s people.

verses.text: They left Rithmah and camped at Rimmon Perez.
verses.comment: Each encampment signifies a stage of spiritual growth, perseverance, or discipline.

verses.text: They departed from Rimmon Perez and camped at Libnah.
verses.comment: Libnah may reflect divine judgment and purity, as its name suggests whiteness.

verses.text: They set out from Libnah and camped at Rissah.
verses.comment: Rissah continues the record of journeys, reflecting the pilgrim life of God's people.

verses.text: They departed from Rissah and camped at Kehelathah.
verses.comment: The name Kehelathah shares a root with ‘assembly,’ anticipating the importance of community worship.

verses.text: They set out from Kehelathah and camped at Mount Shepher.
verses.comment: Mount Shepher means ‘beautiful’ or ‘splendid,’ signifying the hope and glory of God’s guidance.

verses.text: They departed from Mount Shepher and camped at Haradah.
verses.comment: Haradah means ‘fear’—reminding us of the need for holy reverence toward God.

verses.text: They set out from Haradah and camped at Makheloth.
verses.comment: Makheloth again links to ‘assembly,’ pointing toward the communal aspect of worship and faith.

verses.text: They departed from Makheloth and camped at Tahath.
verses.comment: Tahath’s meaning is uncertain, but the progression reveals steadfastness in moving toward God’s promises.

verses.text: They left Tahath and camped at Terah.
verses.comment: Terah is Abraham’s father’s name, alluding to the faith journey from the patriarchs to the promised inheritance.

verses.text: They set out from Terah and camped at Mithkah.
verses.comment: Each stage names the pilgrimage’s progress, relevant to the ongoing spiritual journey of believers.

verses.text: They departed from Mithkah and camped at Hashmonah.
verses.comment: Hashmonah’s location is uncertain, yet it demonstrates faithful observance of the journey laid out by God.

verses.text: They left Hashmonah and camped at Moseroth.
verses.comment: Moseroth is linked to the death of Aaron. The priestly line continues, emphasizing ordained leadership.

verses.text: They set out from Moseroth and camped at Bene Jaakan.
verses.comment: Bene Jaakan is associated with Aaron’s journey. The priesthood remains central to worship and continuity.

verses.text: They departed from Bene Jaakan and camped at Hor Haggidgad.
verses.comment: Hor Haggidgad, with uncertain meaning, still marks a real event in God’s guided journey.

verses.text: They set out from Hor Haggidgad and camped at Jotbathah.
verses.comment: Jotbathah is a place of streams of water—again typifying spiritual nourishment from God.

verses.text: They departed from Jotbathah and camped at Abronah.
verses.comment: Abronah’s name possibly relates to passage or crossing, foreshadowing entry into new life.

verses.text: They set out from Abronah and camped at Ezion Geber.
verses.comment: Ezion Geber’s later significance as a seaport shows the ongoing presence and expansion of God’s people.

verses.text: They departed from Ezion Geber and camped in the wilderness of Zin, which is Kadesh.
verses.comment: Kadesh is a place of decision, testing, and the site of Moses’ disobedience. It emphasizes faithfulness and God’s mercy.

verses.text: They set out from Kadesh and camped at Mount Hor, on the border of Edom.
verses.comment: Mount Hor is where Aaron dies and a new high priest is appointed, foreshadowing legitimate succession and continuity in spiritual leadership.

verses.text: Aaron the priest went up Mount Hor at the command of the LORD and died there, in the fortieth year after the Israelites had come out of the land of Egypt, on the first day of the fifth month.
verses.comment: Aaron’s death is recorded as marking the end of an era. The transition of priesthood reaffirms the importance of mediatory roles in worship and teaching.

verses.text: Aaron was 123 years old when he died on Mount Hor.
verses.comment: The longevity of Aaron highlights the faithfulness and dedication required of spiritual leaders.

verses.text: The Canaanite king of Arad, who lived in the Negev in the land of Canaan, heard of the approach of the Israelites.
verses.comment: This verse introduces resistance on the journey, paralleling the reality that spiritual progress often faces external opposition.

verses.text: They departed from Mount Hor and camped at Zalmonah.
verses.comment: Each encampment brings God’s people closer to the fulfillment of His promises.

verses.text: They left Zalmonah and camped at Punon.
verses.comment: The movement through various locations marks stages of transformation and maturation in faith.

verses.text: They set out from Punon and camped at Oboth.
verses.comment: Oboth’s mention marks forward movement toward the promised land—a type of heaven.

verses.text: They departed from Oboth and camped at Iye Abarim, on the border of Moab.
verses.comment: Iye Abarim, on the border of Moab, forms the final approach to the land of promise—a symbol of fulfilled hope.

verses.text: They set out from Iye Abarim and camped at Dibon Gad.
verses.comment: Dibon Gad recalls God’s victory and provision, building the faith of the people before entering the land.

verses.text: They departed from Dibon Gad and camped at Almon Diblathaim.
verses.comment: Another step toward the inheritance, Almon Diblathaim demonstrates persistence.

verses.text: They set out from Almon Diblathaim and camped in the mountains of Abarim, before Nebo.
verses.comment: Mount Nebo is significant as the place where Moses would view the promised land but not enter. This foreshadows Christ, who brings the people into the kingdom.

verses.text: They departed from the mountains of Abarim and camped in the plains of Moab, by the Jordan across from Jericho.
verses.comment: Camping beside the Jordan sets the stage for the final entry, symbolizing crossing from death to life, connected to baptism and spiritual rebirth.

verses.text: They camped by the Jordan from Beth Jeshimoth as far as Abel Shittim in the plains of Moab.
verses.comment: Abel Shittim becomes a place of temptation and preparation for entry, reflecting the need for purity.

verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses in the plains of Moab by the Jordan across from Jericho, saying:
verses.comment: God prepares to give direct instructions, reminding believers of the necessity of an authoritative, divinely appointed leader.

verses.text: 'Speak to the Israelites and tell them: When you cross the Jordan into the land of Canaan,
verses.comment: Crossing the Jordan represents entry into the promises of God, echoing entering the fullness of spiritual life.

verses.text: You shall drive out all the inhabitants of the land before you. Destroy all their carved images and all their cast idols, and demolish all their high places.
verses.comment: Purging the land of idols stresses the need for purity of worship. Idolatry corrupts, but God calls His people to undivided devotion—prefiguring purity of doctrine and right worship.

verses.text: Take possession of the land and settle in it, for I have given you the land to possess.
verses.comment: The gift of the land is by divine authority, foreshadowing the inheritance promised to all believers through Christ.

verses.text: Distribute the land by lot according to your clans. To a large family give a larger inheritance, and to a small family a smaller one. Whatever the lot falls to each will be theirs. Distribute it according to your ancestral tribes.
verses.comment: The command to distribute by lot shows God’s sovereignty and how He provides for all according to their need—an echo of the spiritual equality in the body of Christ.

verses.text: But if you do not drive out the inhabitants of the land from before you, those you allow to remain will be like thorns in your sides and will trouble you in the land you will live in.
verses.comment: Failing to fully obey brings spiritual consequence. This echoes the call to fully renounce sin and false doctrine.

verses.text: And as I had planned to do to them, so I will do to you.'
verses.comment: God's warnings are serious and just, urging total fidelity. The spiritual lesson is clear: complete surrender to God’s will is necessary for true life and blessing.
